entry.title: Follow The Honey
entry.content:
http://waffleparadox.smugmug.com/Other/Follow-The-Honey/i-kDb523C/0/L/DSC_2978-L.jpg">

A few weeks ago I was dragged somewhat skeptically to a honey store. Yep, that’s right—a honey store. A store, that’s dedicated to honey. I know. Strange as it may sound, it’s actually a thing. But after my (thus far only) trip, I’m a convert.

The storefront is very cozy, nestled within the basement of a building in Harvard Square. The inside is all amber and, to the surprise of absolutely nobody, decorated with various bee-related paraphernalia—Everything from cards with bees to beeswax candles. Why couldn’t I have known about this place back when we were doing caneles? The first attempts with copper molds all but required beeswax; hell, I still prefer that to cooking spray. But I digress.

The workers were all super happy and friendly. I wonder if it was the general almost-hippie peaceful vibe of the interior, but they almost seemed too happy. As in I was almost tempted to ask for the, ahem, “special” honey, so to speak. In any case, they were all perfectly pleasant and helpful and eager to offer samples from the honey bar. Did I mention they have a honey bar? It’s absolutely bizarre. The first question I was asked was “what flavors do you like in your honey?” I have no idea, are you kidding me? I’ve only had the kind in the bear bottles.

I ended up trying a few varieties ranging from the savory and spicy to the sweet and fruity. And it’s like coffee—Once you have the real stuff, you don’t want to go back unless you have no other choice. For my part, I walked out with nearly 3 digits' worth of merch.

http://waffleparadox.smugmug.com/Other/Follow-The-Honey/i-xBT3tP7/0/L/DSC_2989-L.jpg">

The most interesting is probably the Hawaiian honey, which is from bees gathering from flowers off the side of volcanos in Hawaii. If that sounds exotic, don’t worry—It’s got a correspondingly exotic price tag, about 30-some dollars for 8 oz (226g). I bought two jars: one was Kiawe honey infused separately with lilikoi flowers, and one uninfused Macadamia honey. The former actually came in semi-solid form (common for raw honey) and packed a sharp passion fruit flavor. The latter was a more “typical” liquid texture, and rosey gold with a mild nutty flavor.

http://waffleparadox.smugmug.com/Other/Follow-The-Honey/i-RqWvFwQ/0/L/DSC_2990-L.jpg">

In addition to these, I also walked out with two jars of honey gathered from Oaxaca, Mexico. Oaxaca’s a great region for food agriculture—Some pretty good coffee comes out of there as well. This honey was very savory, almost spicey, and a dark maple-syrupy color. It was also very reasonably priced, something like $12-13 for I would guess 12oz out of the keg. Oh, did I mention there were kegs? Honey, on tap. Whodaknownit?

http://waffleparadox.smugmug.com/Other/Follow-The-Honey/i-7QKxJ2M/0/L/DSC_2977-L.jpg">

http://waffleparadox.smugmug.com/Other/Follow-The-Honey/i-hBBmCWs/0/L/DSC_2991-L.jpg">

If it isn’t obvious by now, I’d recommend anyone in the area to stop by at least once, regardless of inherent interest in bees and honey. If nothing else there are very nice people giving out free samples, and who knows? Maybe just a few tastes will be enough.

entry.title: Oysters with Lemon Pearls - Week 11 Molecular
entry.content:
http://waffleparadox.smugmug.com/Food/Oysters-With-Lemon-Pearls/i-5NhtLD4/0/L/DSC_2972-L.jpg">

I was really looking forward to the Molecular theme, since I’d been itching to play with some of this newfangled Modernist Cuisine stuff for a while now. So I went ahead and ordered a spherification kit from amazon, and came up with the idea of pairing spheres with oysters.

The kit came with fairly straightforward instructions, so I just followed those. For my liquid base I used lemonade mixed with lemon juice for acidity. I added 2 grams of sodium citrate, since the kit recommended that for potentially acidic solutions.

The spheres came together fairly well, though it was pretty slow going at first. I’m also displeased that the syringe included with the kit is one use only…

http://waffleparadox.smugmug.com/Food/Oysters-With-Lemon-Pearls/i-p99X433/0/L/DSC_2968-L.jpg">

The spheres look good, but I think that’s about all that I can say about them positively. Taste-wise, they were slightly rubbery and the insides were way too viscous—Closer to maple syrup than juice. Maybe it was the disappointment from expecting something closer to the “popping boba” found in bubble tea/frozen yogurt, but overall I just found the texture unpleasant. In addition, the alginate stifled the acidity in the lemon and left a funny taste in my mouth, making the pearls taste basically like jello filled with slightly off sugar syrup.

All in all, I would have been better served making plain old lemon jello with the oysters, which is what I’ve done in the past. It’s possible that I did something terribly wrong despite my self-perceived precision, or perhaps this kit just didn’t include the right substances for this set of circumstances. Half the instructions seemed to exist for upselling, e.g., “buy our slotted spoon!”, “buy our PH meter!”

Either way, this was a huge disappointment and I don’t see myself trying again any time soon.

entry.title: Coi
entry.content:
https://scontent-a-lga.xx.fbcdn.net/hphotos-prn2/t1.0-9/10366159_10152435781269470_5551473906445502316_n.jpg" width="500" height="500">

Of course it’s just after I dish out a healthy dose of self-deprecation about restaurant writing that I feel compelled to write about another restaurant. So I’ll keep it short.

I went to Daniel Patterson’s Coi recently. The only thing I can say about the food is that it wasn’t overtly over-the-top. Nor was it deliberately modernist or filled with crazy techniques using chemicals I can’t pronounce. But it was very very delicious and still managed to surprise me. I can’t overstate how awesome this is, and would recommend the trip to anyone given to spending unhealthy amounts of money on food.

Also bought a signed copy of the book while I was there. I can’t wait to read it.

entry.title: Whole Chicken Biryani
entry.content:
http://waffleparadox.smugmug.com/Food/Whole-Chicken-Biryani/i-2SMxkfv/0/L/DSC_2941-L.jpg">

And it’s time for yet another episode of “As [I Have] Seen On TV”! This time, I draw inspiration from Ramsay’s Great Escape, in which Gordon gets tired of his financial troubles and career as a TV chef and so decides to… Go off to make more TV. Go figure.

Regardless of motivations, it’s a pretty engaging show. Throughout two seasons, he travels through southeast Asia—India, China, Vietnam, and the like—slumming it with the locals to learn their skills and eventually returning to the “civilized areas” of the country to demonstrate his newfound knowledge. The only real complaint I have is the (hopefully unintended) air of condescension that he develops at times. “Look, these people have absolutely nothing and they still eat like kings! It’s amazing!”

That aside, there are some memorable moments, one of which was a wedding catering to something in the neighborhood of 1000 guests. Ramsay goes back to his line cook roots and helps a chef stuff a goat with some chicken stuffed with quail stuffed with egg which is then loaded into a giant vat of rice. Despite my dreams to own a farm one day I still haven’t the means to pull a goat out of thin air, but I figured a whole chicken biryani might be worth a shot. While I have done biryani before, this was highly experimental, so this will be more of a photo log than set instructions

http://waffleparadox.smugmug.com/Food/Whole-Chicken-Biryani/i-45Rk3rc/0/L/DSC_2943-L.jpg">

First, the chicken was rubbed with oil and lemon juice mixed with biryani-ish spices: cloves, cayenne, cumin seed, coriander, and so on. That was left to sit for a little bit while I par-boiled my rice, and then thrown into a pot to roast with some potatoes. I used my usual temps: 450 for ½ hour, 370 after. In this case I shortened the cooking time a bit, since it still had to cook with the rice.

http://waffleparadox.smugmug.com/Food/Whole-Chicken-Biryani/i-sD6CTSf/0/L/DSC_2944-L.jpg">

After the chicken was done, I deglazed the bottom of the pot and lined it with freshly sliced tomatoes. Then I stuffed some of the rice and potato into the chicken, loaded the chicken and potatoes back into the pot, and covered with the par-boiled rice. I lined the pot cover with a cloth to trap the steam, and it finished in about 45 minutes at a medium-lowish heat.

http://waffleparadox.smugmug.com/Food/Whole-Chicken-Biryani/i-5JQdj93/0/L/DSC_2950-L.jpg">

Overall this turned out pretty well. There wasn’t much deviation from “standard biryani procedure”, which basically just involves cubed meat instead of a whole bird. The biggest pain was getting the meat off the chicken at the end: it came off, but took some effort. Perhaps a longer cooking time, or more moisture to cook the chicken with, next time?

entry.title: Garlic Soy Chicken Wings
entry.content:
http://waffleparadox.smugmug.com/Food/Honey-Soy-Wings/i-ZfrmLNX/0/L/DSC_2936-L.jpg">

Yes, I’m going to be that Asian who posts a chicken wing recipe involving some combination of garlic, soy, and honey. Next thing you know I’ll be writing book reviews for the Joy Luck Club and acting in sketches about Tiger Moms. Though I suppose the latter would be pretty entertaining…

This isn’t the first chicken wing recipe I’ve posted (note to self: still need to port those old entries over…), but it is a pretty quick and easy one. The only awkward part is that in situations like this, it’s not worth the effort to not make a ton, but then everything takes a while to eat… But I think that’s a pretty good problem to have.

  • 3 lb chicken wings
  • 1 cup vegetable oil
  • ¼ cup honey
  • ¼ cup soy sauce
  • ¼ cup Shaoxing wine
  • 4 cloves garlic
  • 1 tbsp brown sugar
  • Pinch of salt

To prepare, mix all the sauce ingredients together, and toss the chicken in. If you’re feeling really bored, jab them a few times to help the sauce seep in. Mix evenly, then let it sit in the fridge overnight. In my experience, the wings can be kept this way for up to 3 days—I’d vouch for longer, but they’re generally eaten in that time frame.

When ready, pre-heat the oven to 375, and bake for about 30 minutes. Do note that I usually cook in batches, so if the whole 3 lb needs to be done at once, 45 minutes would probably be safer. Give them a quick toss on the stove with some fresh herbs. Scallions are usually a pretty good bet, but I like cilantro too.

http://waffleparadox.smugmug.com/Food/Honey-Soy-Wings/i-VS3Xmzp/0/L/DSC_2918-L.jpg">
